review_title: Good pay. Regional leadership disorganized and focused on profits only
pros: Great pay, decent training, decent benefits, and retirement plan.
cons: Very unforgiving. Upper management appears to have no care, or compassion for the employees making the money for the company. Click on a tricky email phishing exercise, you'll lose your bonus. Make a mistake or two...you're gone. Quick to fire, slow to hire. Willing to cut off their nose (employees) to spite their face (manning #s at locations). During record years of profit, no cost of living/merit raises although everything jumped in cost. And then last year a modest increase in wages even though it was a record profit year, whereas most companies were experiencing lulls in their profits. Support for IT and other facets of internal support lack speed of response, efficacy of resolution, and near zero accountability to their customers, the KM field employees.

pros:
If you are not scared of hard work this is a great place to develop your skills. If you can work this pipeline every other pipeline will be a cake walk. You have great job security as long as you are extremely thorough. At first I didn't care for the environment but it grew on me. I actually miss working with my team and if I had the chance to do it over I would have taken it seriously right out the gate. Get right in and learn don't be timid. You will only learn this job if you do not by watching.
Management is substantially improved from the start of my career. John is dialed in and knows what is going on. He is focused on process improvement and from what I could tell he has actually been effective. 
People are favorite thing about the job.
cons: It is hard to move into another position whether that is laterally or vertically. Staff is overworked but not because management doesn't care it is mostly due to how challenging it is to train people fast enough to be prepared to work on their own. The Staff is extremely intelligent and some of the hardest working individuals I've met. That said it is very easy to make mistakes and seeing you are DOT and the hazards that can come with simple errors it is easy to lose your job. Don't be focused on productivity versus thoroughness. I would recommend you focus on thoroughness the productivity will come with time as you skill up. Staff can be a bit jaded because like I said you are overworked and it is a high stress job.

-I appreciated the down-to-business culture. No frills. No pep rally.
-Most I've worked with showed high level of professionalism. All employees whom I've worked closely with were bright.
-Management supported technical growth, and was not frugal as long as clearly justified and beneficial to the role.
-Benefits, pay, and perks were great. It may not be best in class - but it struck a good balance between work-life, pay, and security.
-Middle management and senior leadership were competent, from my observation.
cons:
-Promotion opportunities were hard to come by.
-Although one of the most well known companies in Houston, there were not much community activities taking place.
-If you're straight out of college, and seeking a more early career centered network, KM might not be the best place. You will still build valuable connections, but be ready to work.

pros: Benefits are great! There is a 4-5% yearly contribution to a pension and a 4-5% yearly gift to 401k. Start off with 3-4 weeks of PTO. However PTO must be used for sick leave. 10 Paid Holidays, tuition reimbursement and a bonus. Typically a pretty stable company to work for.
cons:
Management style - Supervisors and Managers have little voice in decisions even though they work with and are more familiar with their employees. 

Raises - Typically are standard cost of living raise or below. You could have the best year or worst year and still get less than a 3% raise. 

Wages - Average to below average. Definitely could make more at other companies.

Work Life Balance - We don't have enough employees to cover our workload and have to work above and beyond to meet our customer's needs. We are supposed to have a 9/80 schedule, but rarely able to have our days off. Couple this with the layoff of our contractors and the recent employee layoffs. We now have a further reduced staff trying to maintain workload. All while we are treated like children and have our 9/80 threatened to be taken away.

The Reorg. - This was supposed to be for efficiency however it is anything but efficient and more of just a consolidation and reduction. Many people were demoted not due to performance. To be honest, it isn't clear why some people maintained their positions while better people were demoted. However it is clear that the upper management was making the decisions with zero input from lower management. Also the handling of the reorg. was anything but transparent even though we were supposed to be kept in the loop. Being kept in the loop meant Upper Management sent out a vague list of where each department would be redirected. However most of the departments were excluded from the list without any clarification. Lower management wasn't in the loop at all and found out our employees were being laid off after said employee called to let us know. 
Post Reorg. we are still scratching our heads on what just happened and worse off than before the reorg. 
If you had asked before this year what my thoughts were of Kinder, I would have replied that it's a great company to work for. After this year I seriously question whether I want to make this my career choice. However this is just for the corporate office, Field locations may be a different story.

pros: As a whole, the job security at KM is outstanding as lay offs are non-existent, the benefits are on par with industry standard, and flexibility within employee's individual schedules is a plus.  The respect and attitudes, employee v. employee, operations v. management are for the most part agreeable which helps with the overall atmosphere of day to day working conditions.  Implementing safety features such as dual verification has helped mitigate controller miscues and provide an important aid for all controllers.  There is plenty of room for growth within KM.  Every sector of mgmt within the terminal has an open door policy and are always willing to listen to any and all thoughts, suggestions, or concerns.
cons: Employee turnover in regards to pipeline controllers has slowed drastically, but is and can be an issue.  The HMI/SCADA for controllers is archaic and training can seem at times as sink or swim.  The overall workload is unprecedented when compared to other Oil and Gas terminals and the pay does not come close to reflecting such output.  Yearly bonuses are below average for controllers and the outline for how bonuses are calculated are poorly conveyed to controllers, especially when compared to the amount of product moved per employee, per console.  Biased towards ex-military and KM has a "mgmt in waiting" program for ex-military.  Although expectations should always be high, mgmt. yields an uncompromising attitude towards controller miscues when you compare the amount of workload and simply product being moved throughout the terminal.

You will have VP, Director, manager and you have emails going left and right with the same question. 5. No standards.

job_title: Terminal Operator in La Porte, TX
pros: Good Money, easy job lots of down time
cons: Low bonuses, managment stuck in there ways

review_title: The best place for C Students to Work
pros: With the acquisition of El Paso Corp they have become the fourth largest energy company.
cons: I cannot believe they have managed to find that many incompetent people to work in one organization. After reviewing this website and the comments made, it is very clear that these descriptions of Kinder Morgan are very, very, accurate. Kinder will do all they can to avoid paying a buck for anything. They believe you should be grateful to work for them. Incompetent management. Clearly people who are happy being average. Zero leadership in all levels in all departments. Did I say, CHEAP? CHEAP! From Kinder's HR - "we pay average, no more." So if you accept a job with them just know you are accepting a (probably) below-average salary. Everyone wears, "many hats" - their words. No one is ever happy. No one smiles. This company will NEVER win a "Best Places to Work" award and what's worse is they are proud of it (see other posts). I have filed two ethics complaints and both have gone unanswered. They have simply closed them out as resolved.

job_title: Director of Operations in Houston, TX
pros: Steady work in operations but also very cyclical.
cons: poor management, micromanaged and poor leadership

pros: Jobs are fairly stable for employees
cons: Command and control environment Which prevents the innovation

pros: Good benefits, SQE culture (safety, quality, environment). Kinder loves the military and will hire military people for leadership positions whether you have experience or not.
cons: Kinder Morgan senior management (above the terminal manager) do not know what they are doing. Communication is lacking from the top down and bottom up too. Trying to get information is like pulling teeth from a new born baby. Watch out for being replaced by a MIT (manager in training) Kinder loves the military and will hire whether they know operations or not, which causes problems of having leaders in place that do not know how to run the place.

pros: It's a job. If you are 4-5 years away from retirement, go for it!
cons:
Unless you are a lifer and can sit through about 20-30 years worth of brain erasing 8-to-5 stuff, filling our spreadsheets for your bosses without making a single decision, without having any say in what's going on whatsoever... do NOT even bother. Even VP level guys barely make any decisions in KM. Director level guys are bragging about managing 5-6 million dollar projects. Perhaps after being burned in Enron, Richard Kinder doesn't want anybody to make any decisions ever.

I don't know a single person who left KM and wasn't happy afterwards. I suffered through 3 years of this stuff until it was painfully obvious that I wasn't going anywhere while watching guys with much less education and experience getting promoted because somebody is pushing them up or pulling them up. You are completely screwed if you don't have any connections in that company. And to develop those kinds of connection, you need to be there 10-15 years. If you are ready for that, more power to you.

I left KM for a job with much more responsibility and MUCH better pay. That is also a recurring theme between most people who leave KM - more responsibility and better pay.

job_title: Heavy Equipment Operator in Houston, TX
pros: Benefits, 401k, pay, good ot, management try to work with you.
cons: Takes awhile to move up

pros:
High base compensation (around 30% higher than similar positions at companies in the same industry)

9/80 schedule for most departments, which means every other friday you get off
Any travel is paid for by you up front, and then compensated by Kinder Morgan, rather than using a company card - so you get all the credit card points, miles, etc.

Motivated workers have good opportunity for advancement if you live in Houston.
cons:
Too management heavy

Company culture of saving every penny often means antiquated systems, bad hardware (old small computer screens, no docking stations, etc.)

Limited opportunity for advancement in satellite offices

Like any huge company, many many policies and procedures and forms for everything.

Minimal training available across the board. Richard Kinder was all about saving money so they don't invest in much. The only thing they spend lavishly on is base salary.

No continuing education allowance

All offices are cube farms with low walls. Only director level and above get offices. Very little privacy.

review_title: it comes down to a simple choice...get busy dying here.....
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Decent Pay,  the bottom rungs of the workforce is friendly and knowledgeable.
cons: Where to start....  runs so slim that spreadsheets are still used for many tasks that have much better and efficient options out there.  Actually had to purchase own or scrounge for office supplies.   Bureaucracy runs so rampant that it seems that the company would step over a dollar to pick up a dime if it shows a profit to shareholders.    Management culture when dealing with employees is to default to  not trusting employees.  Employees are responsible for travel expenses with a reimbursement from the company after completing an arduous and lengthy expense report.  Replacement computers take weeks even if they are almost unusable and old (over 8  years old in my case.)  Work/life balance can be an issue for some employees.   Training is not a priority,  it has been stated "we hire experience" by a member of upper management in reference to training.   Company is not an industry leader in anything that isn't compliance driven like some of the companies that they acquired (don't go above and beyond what is required of them, yet they expect their employees to).   Poor morale across numerous departments.

review_title: Company does great but could do more for their field personal.
pros: Company always looking for a ways to expand is now the number one pipeline company in the US.  Wage is middle of the road. Benefits are OK.
cons: Bonus are bad  they say they are based on performance and other factors they have never been performance driven everyone gets the same bonus at the field level.  Dont get me wrong at least we get a bonus but  when the CEO gives his speeches at least practice what you preach.   Raises are always under 3% no mater how well the company does. Company does better every year but they keep taking things away we used to get stock options....not anymore and used to be able to purchase stock at a discount.....no more.  Those are just a few examples.  The company bought Elpaso recently but by the looks of the new structure you would think kindermorgan was the one who was purchased.  First line supervision needs to get paid more you can make more money in the crew by working a little overtime there is no incentive to move up.

pros:
decent benefits that start from day one
decent pay
plenty of overtime, if that's your thing
stable
cons:
rampant nepotism and cronyism
no set schedule
no recognition for quality work performance and problem solving
weak leadership
no respect for employees
poor work/life balance unless you're management
lots of gossip and backstabbing
poor communication between employees and management

If you aren't related or friends to someone in management, your only chance to advance is to kiss up to management. 

It doesn't matter about the quality of work or experience that you bring to the table. If you are too good at your job you are more than likely to be viewed as a threat and be held back instead of being viewed as an asset. This is due to the lack of qualifications, caring and work ethic that the majority of area and terminal management has.

If you are an ambitious person who takes personal pride in doing a good job and wants to advance in a company by doing it the right way(working hard, learning everything you can and being dependable), look elsewhere. This is a stepping stone job at best.

job_title: Operations Supervisor in New Caney, TX
pros:
5% 401K match.
Company is big enough to be around for a while.
cons:
Cheap  and rigid about everything.  KM makes their own horrid software programs so they can avoid paying for licensing. Make work more difficult making everything some excel based document like it’s 1997, wastes time. 

Company is ran too lean compared to alike companies, each role typically has many more responsibilities compared to others.  You’re constantly firefighting, progress cannot be made. 

LTIP is a carrot on a string. Just another item they threaten to take away. 

Poor culture; they give you the “if you don’t like it, there’s the door” type statement if you can have criticism. 

WORTHLESS HR. I had an issue when I was getting picked on by my manager and tried to transfer to a different department.  I was going to get an offer but was blocked based on a lie about my work performance. HR didn’t even care to look into my complaint. 

I put in my two weeks and HR didn’t even bother to provide an exit interview, or even call to ask why.  Marches to managements orders and isn’t afraid to display it.

pros:
If you enjoy working in the field this role is perfect. You have opportunities to take on collateral duties to gain experience. 

That's IT!
cons:
Very poor hiring practices which fosters a cliquish workplace. An environment of exclusion is fostered and encouraged by Supervisors. There is a lack of integrity that is blatant yet nothing is done. Overall my experience has been poor. If you keep to yourself and push through your day it is tolerable. 

In terms of pay it could definitely be better. Your start  out at $22 and top out at $31. Overtime is virtually non-existent unless you are buddies with a Supervisor (may pick up once the industry improves) 

If you need a job to hold you over while you look, this will positions will do. Of course your experience may be different.

review_title: Look elsewhere if you want a career
pros: Downtown parking or free metro pass is included
cons: This place is where most people look out only for themselves and management is clueless, incompetent, does not care at all, or most likely all three. You have to figure out everything by yourself since training is nonexistent. Accounting uses ancient software that's useless if you work somewhere else (name one other major energy company that uses lawson) and they come up with in-house software that a frantic IT person has to put together since this company is always too cheap to spend on outside help. I knew people who were using 10+ year old laptops from the el paso energy days. The products controller is dumb as rocks and likes to backstab folks, her boss doesn't do anything since they're in the same boat and is probably just waiting it out for retirement. The other groups are not any better. I only saw dumb or mediocre folks staying around while the smart ones leave. Do yourself a favor and look elsewhere if you want a real career.

review_title: Great proving grounds but a long road ahead
pros: Exposure to several facets of the midstream energy industry, great vision at the corporate level, lots of opportunities, decent salaries, easy to rise above the rest.
cons:
Bottom line: The C.O.O. needs to be replaced and the leadership needs to tell the employees the truth: come to work on time, do your job, don't get hurt, and we'll pay you.  Don't make promises you can't keep or intend to keep for that matter.
The organization is extremely silo'd and everyone has their own kingdoms.  I'm surprised the company is as profitable as it is with all the in-fighting that occurs on a regular basis.  
The talent pool is horrendous and nobody wants to hold anyone accountable for their actions consistently.

review_title: Must be friends with the Big Bosses!!!!
pros: Best thing I can say about KM is the benefits package was the one of the best that I have seen around.
cons:
There are way to many to really get into, but just to bring some into the forefront, HR will discuss other people during exit interviews and other meetings that have no relevance to your meeting. Unless your are "best friends" with the boss, you will never go anywhere and feel that you must constantly CYA for fear of reprisal on the stupidest things. The anonymous hotline they encourage you to use if you see any ethical issues is a complete joke! I figured out fairly quickly, that unless you play by the rules laid out in front of you, however unethical they may be, you are labeled a trouble maker and will get no where fast....

It's sad when a supplier can tell you stories about upper management in a department because they had previously worked with them and the same issues applied here.

job_title: Project Controls Supervisor in Houston, TX
pros:
Professional work environment, great people to work with and for, mostly everyone wants to move the company forward/in a positive direction, paid parking/metro (huge plus), supportive staff. Overall I enjoyed most of my team and I miss them. My team rocked I wish them all the best!

Management's ability to not select certain employees who are disgruntled because she/they didn't get the job she/they applied for. Management's ability to not select certain employee's who lack real project controls skills. Management's ability to select employees who think reasonably. Management's ability to choose leaders who are experienced, diverse and able to lead and mentor employees. Overall I had no problem with my team, peers and my management. The management had sound judgement.
cons: Growing pains (still recovering from El Paso Merger), a lot of great ideas, but need one solid voice to take the great ideas and communicate one clear message. More defined processes and procedures.

review_title: Fast-paced Environment-High Expectations-Frequent changes- Strong Compensation, Good Benefits, Strong CEO
pros: Strong compensation and lots of opportunities to advance. I was able to increase my salary over $50K in just 8 years with the company (started as entry-level pay straight out of college) . Benefits package was strong (especially health and 401K) while I was there (much better than what I have now). Was able to work independently and faced new challenges every day. Never got boring or slow.
cons: Very high expectations on performance. In management positions you were expected to work long hours, weekends, and be accessible 24/7. Work-life balance was not great. Constant changes to the organizational structure and management made it difficult to achieve goals. Changes were very frequent. Employees were sometimes on a short lease and there was a tendency to fire or discipline rather than coach/mentor. Culture was created by fear and intimidation. High turnover rate.

review_title: No Work Life Balance in IT
pros: You have a job and some of your coworkers are great
cons: Management does not respect personal time and since the IT department is extremely understaffed overtime and pressure to work during off times is common. The culture is archaic and more of a club where if you are not a yes man and value the company above all else including your family you will not move up (this was emphasized by management at times). It doesn't matter if you are at an important family event on your off time they will call for minor items and demand you leave the event to get to work. Management makes promises that are not usually kept.  The IT department is not valued it seems by senior management so treatment by other departments can be harsh. Also be prepared for crude and inappropriate talk and actions at the workplace. The pay is not nearly enough (below industry standards) to deal with the culture at the company.

review_title: Excellent Company that cares for their Employees
pros: Kinder Morgan focuses on their business and rather than adding frivolous benefits and perks, they pay their people well and let them decide what they want to do with their money. Most of the people that work there are friendly and enjoy their work and work well as a team. As for their policies and procedures, they are written and clear. They are staffed well enough not to be negligent of their work responsibilities but also not so fat that they lay off people by the thousands. Pay and benefits are very good.
cons:
There is some political maneuvering to advance but you will find that at every company.
No paternity leave.

pros: Easy work. Low expectations. VPs make most decision. 9/80 lots of vacation. Benefits are ok. But insurance goes up every year while pay increases less than 2.5%.
cons:
Cheap, greedy and unethical with employees and contractors. Have policies but only follow them when convenient. Hide behind them when they don’t want to address issues.

Most of the VPs in my department had very little knowledge of what was happening day to day. 

Everything about the company is about cost. They nickel and dime employees. They try everything not to pay contractors agreed to rates. IT is a joke. They talk about doing less with more but they have to have 4X the people to do the work when software could be purchased.

Great place if you just want to punch the clock and get a pay check. Just negotiated a good salary before to start. They only give at best a 2.5% increase and good luck on promotions. If they promise anything get it in writing.

pros: Rich Kinder is obviously a solid business man. He is strategic with assets and the company continues to grow. Job security seems high as the workload is intense.
cons: Recent management has been allowed to fill the company with friends and family. Under the old management, things seem to run with relative integrity. Now, positions are filled with unqualified candidates and directors are pressured to hire the "recommended" applicants. Unfortunately some have taken it too far and even gone so far as to hire a former basketball coach as a Safety Consultant. These decisions have an effect on the morale of the people on the team who do value safety and all that KM claims to hold valuable. It was disheartening to watch the steady and then rather rapid decline in the integrity of upper management.

pros: Some good people working for the company
cons: Poor work culture and atmosphere which starts with management. Inappropriate relationships at work from management. Work life balance is not great. Underpaid for what is expected if in operations compared to industry standard. Management find ways to constantly not follow ur policies. Management finds ways to constantly try to punish employees. Excessive turnover. Terrible bonus structure.

job_title: Customer Service Associate in Argo, IL
pros: Benefits, pension plan, can wear jeans every day in the office, 401(K) plan. Small office feel, but know you are working for a very large company.
cons: Attendance points system. You get 1/2 point if you are late and a full point if you call in sick. After three points, you are written up. You feel that any little mistake you make, you will be let go. When you bring up this concern to management, the answer is, "Yes and it's happened before." People are afraid to go to work at the Argo terminal.

review_title: If you are young and have an ambition, stay away
pros:
-Stable
-Benefits on par with anywhere else
-Once hired, it is borderline impossible to lose a job in KM

That's about it.
cons:
-Promotions are scheduled 10 years in advance. If you see a new job on the job board, chances are somebody is already picked, HR is just going through legal motions
-A LOT of not very bright people in management just because they stuck around from the beginning and were moved up because somebody else left. Pretty much the only way to move up and is to stick around long enough until somebody leaves/dies.
-The "we don't need a Cadillac if a Chevy would do" mentality leads to people shooting for the Yugo level of performance
-Micromanagement is insane
-Young motivated ambitious people leave left and right because of the "yes" man culture

review_title: A stepping stone at best - a cautionary tale for most of us
pros:
- Growth company with significant assets
- From the outside, company looks like a good team to join
- Money is decent.  Beats unemployment
cons:
- Micromanagement on a level that I thought was only in fiction before working here.
- Culture of fear, CYA, and excuse making.  The first order of business is always to deflect blame.
- Zero chance for advancement if you have skills.  Skills and vision scare them
- Rampant nepotism 
- Comically bad HR/IT/training/internal systems.  The management does not care, and it shows.  When questioned, they will ADMIT that they don't care, saying "people are lined up to work here".  Not for long.
- Promotions and management roles are given (not earned), and go to people who won't make waves or question management.  There is no consideration of skill/ability/education.  A "yes man" lacking abilition, curiosity, or willingness to grow the position is the perfect candidate for a long management career in KM Terminals.
- CHEAP approach to *everything*, unless you are in the good ol' boys club

review_title: Incompetent management, a lot of nepotism.
job_title: Crew Leader in Port Arthur, TX
pros:
Good benefits
Steady work
Good safety program
cons:
Below industry average for pay
Incompetent management
Nepotism
  Managers  seem to be set on demeaning and trying to make their better employees look bad to take the spotlight off the fact that they have no clue or ambition to do their job; when usually that employee is more qualified to do their job. This is perpetuated by the fact that upper management is totally lacking in their job duties. It almost seems that they are " covering" each others backs. There is almost no onsite supervision from managers on up the chain of command. As long as the manager pencil whips his paperwork on the computer and forwards it to the proper people

pros: You are at least employed
cons:
I would not Recommend applying for or giving Kinder Morgan your time when they have a job posting. The company culture is one that is a “Good Ol Boy” system. Management will promote and take care of employees that they favorite. Any employee who has different views such as embracing diversity, liberal mindsets or care about being politically correct will be raked over the coals. I was constantly devalued and treated like I was the scum of the company. This harassment by management has had lasting mental and emotional impacts that still linger in my life.
Not only does this company treat people who are different bad, but their pay is not competitive for the industry and their benefits are decent at best.
If I was you, and you are in IT, I would look elsewhere. This is not a good place to work, and should be avoided like the plague.

pros: There are always projects to work on and plenty of resources to pull from in terms of resources and connections. The office is in a great area and there are many friendly faces at the office. Most coworkers are great to be around and happy hours and potlucks are a great way to schmooze. Lots of opportunities to grow here and work your way up the ladder.
cons: Project management is often obsessed with the bottom line in the near term, that they end up delaying projects and extenuating costs overall. Technology is lacking heavily with not much access to databases or software that competitors have. Very conservative tone with some employees that at the very least is rude, not to say is borderline harrassment. Read the fine print of the HR manual to really get a sense of how the company is run.

pros: There are none!  There are none!
cons: Working at Kinder Morgan was a horrible  experience.  If you have any motivation in life to do well LEAVE NOW.  The management is horrible.  If you know more than them, you're screwed!  They will treat you like dirt and find a way to get rid of you.  I have witnessed on numerous occasions managers covering for each other.  It's comical how many mistakes the management makes.  But they don't admit it.  Very dishonest company.  If you're not willing to bend over, you're not gonna go for.  Very understaffed.  Galena Park is probablly the worst of all terminals.  If Rich Kinder only knew some of the scandelous things that go on there.

review_title: Excellent experience in the industry for recent college graduate!
pros:
- Small team environment even within a larger office
- projects make for a dynamic work day and allow for occasional travel
- supervisor is supportive of training in company and with consultants
- office is easy to navigate and most coworkers are very friendly
-consultants take us out for lunch oftentimes to get to know them and for them to offer resources
- more informal, self-taught, independent job oftentimes, yet with a safety net
-very flexible hours
cons:
- project managers often stifle projects and permits
- solely about the bottom line for projects
- slow to adapt to new technology
- complex invoicing and accrual process for projects
- cubicle-style workspace; lots of sitting in the office

review_title: Established and consistently great company with untapped potential.
pros: This a focused company with very defined goals and a consistent record of achieving these goals.  These targets are both financial and performance oriented, and they are made public.  These goals are the standard by which performance is measured, and all are consistently held to the standard.  This works because there is no question about what the performance objectives are who did or did not achieve them.
cons: The focus seems to be too short term.  Efficiency and capacity suffer because of short term goals.  Long term vision is not communicated well to lower levels.  Likewise, the ideas and suggestions of employees are nor communicated up through levels of management.

pros: There were no pros at this location.
cons:
I worked at the Charleston Shipyard River Terminal South and it was the worst employment experience I have ever had, that terminal is a cancer. The management was the absolute worst I have ever seen. From pure laziness to having absolutely no clue how to manage people or day to day operations. They will throw anyone under the bus in a heartbeat to make themselves look good. All the employees hated each other and refused to work together and help each other out. That terminal is a disaster waiting to happen. 

Save yourself the misery and go work at any other terminal in the surrounding area. You will make more money and won't be worked into the ground for minimal pay.

review_title: Great Regional Offices, Corporate Not So Much
pros: I worked in a regional office that had been a corporate office of a company Kinder Morgan acquired.  Pay was excellent and above average for the area.  Much of the personality of the former company had remained and it was the least political office I ever worked in.  Coworkers were great and though the phrase is cliche, we were family.  Deep friendships were common.
cons: The down side to Kinder Morgan is the corporate office and most of the stress I felt on the job originated there, not from my office.  Though only separated by a few floors, interacting departments, (e.g. Project Management and Procurement),  rarely communicated face to face or participated in meeting with each other.  Some corporate employees including management were arrogant and condescending to those not in Houston.  Company's constant focus on "cost" is ridiculous and emotionally draining over time.  Computers are refreshed on a 7 year cycle and most of the programs and systems are home grown and seem 15 years behind the times.  Not only are they cumbersome to use, most don't talk to each other, so you have to go to multiple places to  get your information.  Company has a very antiquated management style with the only progressive thing available being several flex-schedule options, but no telecommuting.  Company recently centralized a department justifying it with a Jedi mind trick story full of corporate double speak.  Bottom line, was a specific business unit had multiple instances of fraud so lets just bring everyone to Houston so we can micro-manage.  The whole move speaks volumes about managements incompetence and inability to manage remote employees.  Executive leadership continues to implement the same old fashioned thinking and practices of the primary founder.  Listen to any executive VP or higher and you get the feeling this is how companies were run in the early careers of our parents.  The stock price has been in the bottom of the peer group for years, with much smaller companies out performing them.  The only reason my rating isn't a 2 or less is because of the pay and the fact I didn't have to put up with the drama in Houston everyday.

job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Houston, TX
pros: Kinder Morgan's policy of fiscal responsibility is the leading reason why they are such a stable company.  The management has a no-nonsense attitude that is refreshing.  Kinder Morgan is large enough to provide good benefits while still small enough to avoid feeling like a number.  The employees are generally friendly and team-oriented.
cons: Kinder Morgan takes frugality a little far sometimes.  This can be frustrating because it seems to be a hit or miss attitude and they sometimes choose to cut costs in areas where it does not seem wise or impactful.  The company is a little quirky due to the personalities in upper management, but overall it is a great place to work.  I would definitely consider working there in the future.

pros: Kinder Morgan offers employees excellent health benefits.  Headquarters are located in Houston, Texas with regions scattered across North America.  Travel opportunities abound here as regions can span many states.
cons: I was told when I interviewed at Kinder Morgan that they kept a 'lean staff'.  Beware! This translates into excessively long work days (including weekends and holidays) with seemingly little recognition from management for your efforts.  Salary does not reflect the amount of responsibility or workload expected from staff.  Witnessed questionable hiring tactics (nepotism) that resulted in quite a bit of turmoil for the staff impacted by the hiring decision.

pros: Steady paycheck. Huge company has potential for a good working environment (depends on immediate management). Flexible work schedules.
cons: Cheap, cheap, cheap. Some management types are more ridiculous than others, but it's all about the bottom line.  Return on investment is unheard of at this place.  It's more about how much you can save today, who cares about tomorrow? type attitude. It's like they're running a company with 12 people instead of 12,000 with some of the archaic systems that are in place.

pros:
- 9/80
- Good teammates to work with
cons:
- Micromanagement 
- no work life balance
- expects everything to be perfect and scrutinizes mistakes
- thrives on a chaos environment
- no planning and management skills
- lack of advancement for outstanding performers 
- Make you come in on your holidays/Approved PTO "in case there are questions" and then tell you "to look busy", wasting your time when you can be home with your family.

pros: Company is run well from an investment standpoint so any investment in company shares will do well.  Company is large and has many opportunities to move around to different jobs if you chose.
cons: I do not feel that they value employees as assets.  They are very tight with technology improvements which in the long run cost more due to inefficiencies, and frustration.  Certain departments are more concerned with when you come and go for the day than the quality and/or quantity of work performed by an individual.

review_title: "A Different Kind of Energy Company" - A Step Backwards
pros: Fantastic co-workers at the operations level.
cons: Expectations often exceeded resources. Staying within budget seems to be the sole metric in which managers were evaluated, quality of work and condition of assets/program were secondary. Chronic man-power shortages in various positions/departments. Industry experience and common sense often overlooked in favor of excessive policies with little to no recourse for discussion or revision  (common-sense is an uncommon virtue). Training and operator qualifications model resembled something from you would expect in a retail operation. Lack of adequate mentoring for newer employees. Expect a whole lot of micro-management regardless of position or title. Low morale in the trenches.

job_title: Senior GIS Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: Company is healthy and busy, diverse staff, reasonably positive and supportive management, fairly relaxed, don't have problems with micromanagement, have been able to make career progression, good retirement, good pay, free parking or paid park and ride, good health benefits, great downtown location with tunnel access, updated, ergonomic, and pretty, pleasant offices. It's a good place for a self-starter.
cons: PTO is painfully skimpy. Some managers are too hands off and not providing needed leadership. Coordination and communication between different groups is not always good. Almost nothing in the way of team building activities. People are less bonded with their coworkers. There is not always detailed training provided, so not a great place for people wanting to be taught.

review_title: Strong company with great future prospects.
pros: Kinder Morgan is a great company that is run very efficiently. In contrast with other reviews I found on the internet, I think the senior management is very sharp and know how to keep a cash cow mooing. Also, management (in the Argo office at least) does an excellent job handling problems within the terminal whether it be between employees, engineering problems, whatever.
cons: I think your chances of getting cancer increase dramatically since many of the fuels contain known cancer causing agents. This is strongly shot down at Kinder Morgan but it does not take an idiot to figure out that breathing, interacting and working with these chemicals everyday could increase your chances.

review_title: 0 professional development available at this company,
pros: EVERYONE leaves at quitting time
cons: Very much a big company/corporate culture.  You are lost in the numbers, everyone is looking to CYA

review_title: No work life balance, bad benefits, low compensation, heavy favortism
pros: Lots of challenges to keep you on your A game.  You get to know some nice people in the company.
cons: Managment favors some and allows their favorites to do whatever they want. The benefits get worse every year. Managment has no care for your personal time, forcing overtime on weekends and late nights with no care of current or future plans outside of work. You will not move up unless you are in the "good ol boys" group.  You work with old technology and you do not enhance your career or resume.  The compamy only wants yes men who do not challange managment if you have any innovative or more efficient ideas for projects.

review_title: Both the pluses and minuses are fairly extreme.
pros: On an overall basis, they exhibit a lot of interest in their employees and value the necessity of balancing work and a personal life.  Base pay is average but bonus structure lucrative for some.
cons: Kinder Morgan uses what some describe as "matrix management" whereby an employee really must serve two masters whose goals and requirements may not align very well.  There is also quite a cast system there that favors former employees of Enron Corp.

pros: I left the job b/c I found a job that met my skills and background more than the one at this employer.  The pay is not great, but it is what's to be expected for the area.  They do offer nice perks, such as several holidays and many benefits.
cons: The management allows unacceptable behavior at this location.  I saw the same person get away w/ not doing her part on a daily basis that was regularly called to her attention.  The entire time I was there, no changes were made in her behavior and nothing was ever really done about it.  Even years after I had left, employees still there were going through the same thing.

pros: Competitive salary, respect for personal time, great benefits, challenging roles.  I enjoy working for Kinder Morgan in a mid level management role.  I am given the respect I earn and can expect to move upward should opportunities open.
cons:
Very little to compensation for higher education.
Senior management are at times like a good old boys club. That can be expected in any organization, though.  A few of the senior managers are complete narcissists, and you end up dealing with personality conflicts that shouldn't be the responsibility of the employee.  Bit, I guess you get that anywhere.

review_title: CAN WE SAY...DINOSAUR? OLD SCHOOL PRACTICES - LACK CULTURE - OVERWORKED FOR THE PAY!
pros: Outstanding benefits. Great, friendly and loyal co-workers / employees. Clean & safe work environment.
cons: Be prepared to work long hours , tons of overtime during ME closing and some weekends . Accounting department not streamlined. Poor accounting software. Wear too many hats and have to put out "too many fires" during and outside of month end close.  Too much work for the pay. Antiquated management style and micro-management a normal practice. No room for growth.

review_title: middle management at time useless, lacks accountability; nepotism, hiring friends or like blabbers
pros: used to be a place where hard work and ethics were rewarded; with some serious change in management in the recent years this culture is gone
cons: middle management is at time useless, lacks accountability; nepotism, hiring friends or like blabbers; hard working people with less of these skills targeted as scape goats. I had seen middle to senor managers who had the math skills of a toddler, but were more than capable to write mile long unfavorable reviews for imaginary issues

pros: Stable company to work for during a difficult time within the O&G industry.
cons: Company could improve on employee training/development and recognition.

review_title: Kinder Morgan Pinney Dock Ashtabula HORRIBLE!!
pros: Don't have any, and definitely do NOT go into this company as a temp.
cons: poor management, ZERO training and when you do get it, its taught wrong and then you are held accountable, lay offs out of no where on a small and large scale, during my time there I witnessed approximately 10 high ranking individuals be laid off or let go completely out of the blue with no warning, company is not held to their word and a lot of empty promises are made in the administration office to temps that go through People Ready... just be warned is all, I and a few others wish we had been

pros: Good short term stepping stone into the industry, decent benefits. Always hiring due to high turnover, especially if you are military.
cons: Way low compensation for the volume of work expected compared other controller positions in the industry. Management is under qualified and ruthless, which is one of the main reasons for the high turnover there. Would only recommend if you are desperate or are looking for a short term place to gain some experience.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: Knowledgeable management from top to bottom! Weekly forecasting helps keep everyone informed of every dollar moving on the P&L, all the way up to the exectives. There is never a surprise at month end. People are great to work with.
cons: "Cheaper is better" is not always the right move but to our executive team they believe a penny we can save is extra cash that should go back to our shareholders. I believe that to an extent. Kinder can invest in a new transportation systems and financial forecasting system. I think Kinder can spend more money to help boost employee moral.

review_title: Unsafe and Unethical in SE Region - From a former Terminals Safety Professional
pros: Unfortunately, I cannot think of one Pro.
cons: Sr. Management wants low injury rates, but has not idea what it takes. Rather than develop solid programs and a cooperative culture, the COO has implemented a culture of fear and discipline around safety. Employees and management fear reporting....now you have your low numbers. Unfortunately, the low numbers are gained via unethical methods. Regional Manages lie to try to get information and influence. Everything is done on a shoe string budget, therefore improvement is nearly impossible.

review_title: Kinder Morgan CO2 should be called should be called “Kinder Morgan Family and Friends”
pros:
Average pay and benefits.
Normally a 40 hour work week.
cons:
There are three ways to achieve a high paying position.
•	Friend or family of upper management (i.e. director level or above).
•	Native of Bolivia (subcategory of family and friends).
•	Former Shell employee.

This is not an exaggeration, the amount of nepotism and cronyism is unbelievable!  If HR actually implemented a policy preventing relatives from working and even supervising each other 2/3 of the staff would be eliminated. This would stop all productivity as a few people do all the work for the friends and family network as qualifications are not a requirement for employment. 

This is the cheapest upstream oil and gas company in the country. Saving money is normally a good thing; however they will spend a dollar to save a dime.  Standard policy is to pay an extra $1,800 on a company truck to have the power windows and door locks removed.

pros: Good company to work for I was compensated extremely well upon elimination of my position after 11 months service
cons: There is no system to abide with for executing projects, each project manager has the liberty to piece mill the engineering and construction of his project at will. There is no audit or check balance to verify what the PE is doing is in the best interest of the company.

review_title: No Work/Life Balance.... No benefits that make staying worthwhile.
pros: Still trying to come up with a good list of Pros. If you can just do your job you could have employment for life.
cons: They do not care about working environment, innovation, and new ways to do things. They do not train their employees or provide anything to them to help them do their jobs other than an old computer.

pros: The best thing about working for Kinder Morgan is the 9-10% company contribution to retirement without having to contribute anything. They have a decent PTO program (4 Weeks starting) and have a 9/80 schedule.
cons: You do not receive sick time. If sick you must dip into your PTO. The pay is typically below what other companies pay and you are told that at least you don't have to worry about your job. We are really contractor heavy and due to the low pay, we typically scrape the bottom of the barrel of the talent pool.

review_title: This review is for the Argo, IL terminal only.
pros: Lots of overtime - Good benefits and pay - Most supervisors are good to work for.
cons: The company continues to allow a bully (KK) to work at the Argo, IL site - Get rid of him already.

pros:
Focused on safety and promoting a safety culture.

Lots of experience and keeps on employees that came on through acquisitions.

Gain lots of experience with a variety of commodities.
cons:
Lots of micromanaging from the corporate office in Houston.

Lots of people trying to play the "gotcha" game rather than help

Old equipment and facilities with very limited capital investment to keep operations running at the right levels.

Ignores people that don't toe the party line

job_title: Project Controls Supervisor in Houston, TX
pros: A paycheck.  thats about it.  20 word minimum huh.  Wow. Cronyism to the max.  It sums up to, "The smart never come and the dumb never leave".
cons: situations that shouldn't cause stress are manifested into full blown drama.  No one is ever promoted unless they are friends of upper management.  Attrition is comparable to a fast food joint.  If you enjoy working with hillbillies you've come to the right place.

review_title: No nonsense CEO with great oil, natural gas, and refining product pipeline opportunity.
pros: Kinder Morgan is still in CO2 exploration, production and transportation. Since acquiring El Paso, it is a great company in energy pipeline business with operational excellence. Upper management can make fast decisions. Middle management are willing to apply technologies.
cons: Due to CEO Rich Kinder is an executive with extensive pipeline experiences, the company's focus is in pipeline. Even with KM's excellent position in the CO2 business, their value added investment in oil and gas exploration and production properties is lagging.

pros: Incredible business plan.Committed, down to earth work team. Strong benefits - medical/401k/bonus... A lot of room for career growth if you are willing to put in the time and effort. Promotion from within. The company places a lot of resources into training strong leaders that do not have the industry specific experience. The company is lean, starting at the top, the leaders don't use corporate money for special perks like jets, box seats etc. The CEO, Mr. Kinder, is well respected and admired, as long as he is leading KM will continue to grow.
cons: A lot of turnover in management. The division I worked in is standardizing all facilities across the country. It makes a lot of sense from a corporate perspective, but resulted in a lot of constraints that added up quickly. A lot of the new policies resulted in slower project turn around times, rougher labor relations, and higher costs, but the pressure to perform remained the same. The speed at which a lot of the slogans and policies came down completely committed to the Company and prepared to always be on call. It is not a bad place to be if you are okay with always supporting the job. Benefits are decent and there is room to grow, but it is not something you can close up and walk away from at night or on the weekends. There are environmental concerns with spills and many 24 hours facilities.

review_title: The core value “Commitment to Employees” is laughable
pros: Starting compensation is decent along with bonuses and benefits.  Upper management does a pretty good job navigating trying economic times to make sure as little layoffs happen as possible.
cons: It is very hard to get actual raises. The yearly “merit” increase doesn’t cover yearly cost of living increases. Professional development is non existent and therefore it is very hard to advance on a career path.  This company is all about the bottom line and returning value to shareholders. The side effect is that the support to employees is minimal.

pros: provides benefits like health care and dental and vision.  They have a good retirement program and 401k.  Pay is above the industry standard.
cons: Long hours on shift work (12hr shifts).  A lot is expected to be done in a shift which is usually unfeasible so employees have high stress.  Almost everyone I work with is unhappy with their career.

pros: Overall atmosphere is a good one. Everyone seems to get along and are generally helpful.   One does get assistance if/when needed! Working together works!
cons: Long hours, lack of appreciation value. There is no input wanted from the workers because it's all about upper management and what they need/want. Many improvements needed, but it's all about growing. Meanwhile, infrastructure is crumbling because $$$ is put elsewhere.

review_title: Talk is cheap, that is why there is a great abundance of it at Kinder Morgan...
pros:
My experience is limited to Terminals.  Some good people work within the organization at the lower levels that I was exposed to, maybe there are some at the top too, I wouldn't know.  I was but a low level manager.  It is unfortunate that good people are part of the greater corruption and greed that fuels the very unethical behavior.  Many have been there to long to leave or have been unable to find anything better.

I have actually heard from colleagues who internally transferred to other parts of the business, such as pipelines, that they are run much more effectively and ethically than terminals.
cons:
Again, my experience is limited to Terminals.  Questionable firings, falsified incident reports, and ALWAYS putting shareholder value above all else including safety.  Safety is sort of important when handling dangerous chemicals and petroleum...  

Job security is laughable even if you are regarded as a good performer.  In the two and half years that I worked for KM Terminals, the following happened:  

1.  Regions were realigned and about 20 mid-level managers were terminated in a "Night of the Long Knives" scenario when they were told on a FRI morning that their jobs were no longer needed. 

2.  Questionable firings of lower level managers.  The terminations of lower level managers that I witnessed seemed rather random as if someone looked in a magic 8 ball and determined that whatever the less than optimal situation was warranted a firing. 

The guidance and policies change as often as the wind shifts direction.  There is an almost palpable sense of 'you better watch your back' in daily affairs.  Infighting, and shifting blame are the order of the day.  

I think all of these cons are a result of the sad reality that KM will simply not spend the money to improve their infrastructure and staff their organization adequately.  It seems that upper management, read VP and above, have decided to take a 'lets discipline and fire people a lot so that we can show our chain of command and governmental agencies that we are serious'.    

For the record, I was not fired but I easily could have been.  It is just that random and the threat always looms.  I had some good times at KM and it was a learning experience.

review_title: Don't be afraid to leave quick.  No money to be made on bulk side of km
job_title: Heavy Equipment Operator in Houston, TX
pros: Health insurance is great pension is ok.  Your  crew really makes days go by and to deal with the bs
cons: They have the if you don't like it here than there's the door ,and they'll tell you that in a meeting. No home time  have work a lot of OT just to live comfortably once ot is  gone live pay check to pay check. No advancement  unless you know someone on liquid side.

pros: Team is tight and supportive. Because they are in the same trench dealing with the same shrapnel.

Micromanagement, constant second guessing, and dumbing down complex situations for management to digest... and they still make the wrong decision.

pros: Company is aggressive in growth as evidenced by the recent acquisition of ElPaso Gas.  Employees are not micromanaged, in fact administrative/compliance activities keep management so busy they have less contact than ideal.

Management doesn't look out for advancing our careers.  They just want to keep the consoles staffed and not have to hire anyone for 30 years.  Expressing any advancement is shot down very quickly.

review_title: This was the worst job I've ever worked.  Moto per management " Well Kinder Morgan's not for everyone".  Encouraging Huh

review_title: Good place to find a job, not a career

pros:

review_title: Incompetence, unprofessionalism, short-sightedness and self-preserving focus are just some of the major problems.
pros: The health insurance benefits are good. There are a lot of examples of what not to do, which can be a very valuable learning tool.
cons:
The management in the Lower River Region is incompetent. There is no planning, no communication and the managers are primarily focussed on preserving their careers at all costs. Initiative is discouraged, yet there is no guidance to direct progress. When employees have to take initiative due largely to a "tenured" employee shirking their responsibility, that task suddenly becomes the responsibility of the initiative-taker. There is no effort to retrain the ineffective employee or define work responsibilities and hold employees accountable to specific, defined responsibilities. Employees at the lower levels are treated with disdain and animosity when they point out unsafe or inefficient processes or equipment. When something does go wrong, efforts are directed at blaming a low level employee who can be made into a scapegoat and summarily dismissed. There is no significant root-cause analysis conducted, and when it is, the reports are editted to ensure no blame or responsibility falls on the shoulders of the senior reporting managers. Most of the terminals in the lower river region were previously, "Mom-and-Pop," terminals. Consequently, there are a lot of different programs, policies and procedures in place. Maintenance programs are typically ineffective if they exist at all. Work flow and inter-department communication is negligible. There is no effort to create any kind of process standardization. Kinder Morgan, in response to threats of disciplinary action from the EPA, put together a Terminal Asset Group (TAG) that was supposed to standardize equipment, policies and procedures throughout the Bulk and Liquid Terminals. But, as with most things derived from regulatory threat, it has largely fallen by the wayside; giving way to profit margin and management bonus pressures (It is understood that the EPA will not take serious action against a $100 billion energy company). While the upper executive branch puts out well-documented statements calling for quality focus, customer care and above all safety, these seem to only serve the purpose of making sure the Kinder Morgan legal team has a sufficient stack of documentation proving their executives are not liable for the actions of the employees. These philosophical guidelines are never expounded upon or broken down into cogent processes, policies or procedures.

This is a very frustrating place to work. If you have any other options I suggest you strongly consider them. This is a good stop-gap measure for a pay-check and that is about it, certainly not a serious contender for a career.
